Thank you Anatoli, I think you are right and the results I calculated 
wer=
e reasonable. On the other hand, the reaction starts very close to 
the inl=
et when the initial temperature is 1373K, which should be 
resulted from au=
toignition.

Best wishes.

Changye Liu

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "av=
mokhov" <avmokhov@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
> Your calculations don't look cra=
zy. The reason is a high inlet gas 
> temperature. Approximately, the adiab=
atic flame temperature 
increases 
> as the preheating temperature divided =
by two. You preheat more than 
> 1000 K your unburned gas mixture, therefor=
e, the flame temperature 
> should be around 2000 + 1000/2 ~ 2500 K. More i=
mportantly, I am 
> afraid that the temperature of the unburned gases could=
 not 
> correspond to the physical reality. It seems that this temperature =

is 
> above the mixture's autoignition temperature. In this case it means =

> that this mixture can exist only very short (a few milliseconds or 
> le=
ss) time before autoignition.
> 
> Best regards, Anatoli 
> 
> --- In cante=
ra@yahoogroups.com, "changye_liu" <changyeliu@> wrote:

N2

The initial temperature is 1373K. But the result

e adiabatic temperature is over 2500K and 
the

hat's impossible I think. So there should 
be
